Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Analysis of Fumarole Acoustics at Aso Volcano, Japan
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports research to characterize the sound from fumaroles to advance the understanding of sound produced from volcanic processes. Fumaroles are vents in active volcanic environments that issue steam and other volatiles (i.e. carbon dioxide, sulfur dioxide, etc.) at temperatures greater than 100Â°C. Pressurized gas jetting out of fumaroles also produces sound waves. Fumarole acoustics and degassing can inform us about current and future volcanic activity, as changes in the acoustics and volcanic emissions can be precursors to larger volcanic eruptions. Volcanic jet noise is a direct measure of the pressure fluctuations produced during an eruption and can provide information on the eruption column itself. Jet noise is produced by sustained, momentum-driven fluid flow through a nozzle, such as that of a jet engine, while volcanic jet noise is a sustained acoustic signal produced from the volcanic jet during sustained eruptions. In the latter, the nozzle is the vent of the volcano. Acoustics of laboratory jet engine noise reveals a relationship between the jet noise and the jet?s physical characteristics (velocity, diameter, mass flux, etc.). However, this relationship is still poorly understood for volcanic jets and volcanic jet noise. The research will be conducted under the mentorship of Dr. Takahiro Ohkura and Dr. Akihiko Yokoo of the Aso Volcanological Laboratory at Kyoto University.

One of the goals of the volcano acoustics community is to quantitatively relate sound from volcanic jets back to the eruption itself, but due to the complexities of volcanic jets and field environments this goal has been elusive, thus additional data are needed. This project aims to advance our understanding of volcanic jets and eruption columns by investigating the jet noise produced by fumarolic activity, and then disseminate this information to various volcano observatories and the general scientific community. We will deploy two arrays of infrasound microphones with some collocated with seismometers, at Aso Volcano, Japan to observe and characterize fumarole acoustics and determine their seismo-acoustic signature. Forward Looking Infrared Radiometer (FLIR) cameras will also be used to observe gas emission dynamics, as gases are invisible to the human eye. This NSF EAPSI award is funded in collaboration with the Japan Society for the Promotion of Science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Large volcanic eruptions like the 1980 Mount St. Helens eruption or the 1991 eruption of Mount Pinatubo, known as plinian eruptions, have been recorded with microphones in more recent years. The acoustic signals recorded from recent, 2006 and 2008, subplinian to plinian eruptions at Tungurahua volcano, Ecuador are highly similar to those produced by the momentum-driven fluid flow through a nozzle from a human-made jet or rocket, but at lower frequencies. This momentum-driven fluid flow through a nozzle is known as jet flow or jetting and the sound it produces is called jet noise. The human-made jet noise community has derived equations through extensive testing and data collection that relate the recorded sound to jet parameters such as jet velocity. Herein lies our interest in volcanic jet noise produced by momentum-driven flow of gas, ash and particles from the volcanic vent. Our goal is to relate the acoustic signal produced by volcanic jetting to the jet’s physical parameters. One challenge in volcanic jet noise research is the equations derived from human-made jet noise studies do not hold for the volcanic case. This is due to the complexities of volcanoes such as the presence of particles (e.g. ash and larger rocks) in the flow and non-circular, ever-changing vent shape. In turn, the volcanic jet noise community seeks to derive equations relating volcanic jets to their acoustic signal. Another challenge in this pursuit is acoustic observation. First, the sound from jet flow does not radiate equally in all directions; it changes as you move in an arc from down stream to up stream of the flow. This makes it necessary to observe a volcanic jet at many different angles along that arc, but thus far our microphones are limited to ground surface deployment. Second, large volcanic eruptions do not happen everyday and are highly dangerous to deploy instruments near. This project investigated jet noise produced by a small vent in a volcanic environment that issues steam and other gases at temperatures great than 100C, known as a fumarole.

 

Fumaroles have been reported to produce jet noise and are more accessible compared to larger volcanic eruptions. The goals of this project were to characterize the acoustic signal from fumaroles and to evaluate their potential usefulness as natural laboratory volcanic jets. To achieve this we deployed a temporary array of six microphones at the summit of Aso volcano, Japan along the crater rim and recorded the acoustic signal from a fumarole in the bottom of the crater. The array was ~250 meters from the fumarole and at an observation angle of ~54 degrees down from the vertical axis of the jet flow. The acoustic signal from the fumarole was jet noise as we observed it to be a sustained, tremor-like signal with spectral content that was broadband, meaning there were not any sharp, dominant peaks in the frequency content. The signal covers a broad range from 5 to 25 Hz with the peak frequency between 8 and 10 Hz. During the field campaign, the research team observed the fumarole degassing to sound like a jet as if an airplane were flying just overhead; further evidence that fumaroles produce jet noise. Initial efforts at comparing our data from fumarole jet noise to jet noise produced by large volcanic eruptions suggest the two are comparable. In turn, studying the acoustics of gas jetting fumaroles may be an ideal natural laboratory for advancing our knowledge of volcanic jet noise.

 

This project was proposed and led by a female, early-career scientist. She has presented the results at the American Geophysical Union Fall Meeting 2015, a university seminar and two different volcano observatories: Aso Volcanological Laboratory and Alaska Volcano Observatory.
